description:
Phytophthora cactorum is a plant pathogenic oomycete, commonly known as the cactus blight or crown rot pathogen. It is a member of the Oomycota, a group of water molds that are not true fungi but rather are more closely related to brown algae.

Phytophthora cactorum is an obligate plant pathogen that infects a wide range of hosts, including many species of cacti, as well as fruit trees, ornamental plants, and agricultural crops. It can cause serious diseases such as crown rot, root rot, and stem cankers in susceptible plants.

The pathogen produces several types of spores, including motile zoospores that can swim through water and infect plant tissues, as well as thick-walled resting spores called oospores that can survive in the soil for extended periods. Infection typically occurs through the roots or wounds in the plant, and the pathogen can spread rapidly through the plant's vascular system, leading to wilting, dieback, and eventual plant death.

Phytophthora cactorum is an important target for disease management in horticulture and agriculture, and various control strategies, such as the use of resistant cultivars, chemical fungicides, and cultural practices, have been employed to mitigate its impact on affected plant populations.
